discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
You use a CSSM satelite wheter it be in connected or disconnected mode. Or you can use a HTTPS proxy too, however neither a subscriber nor the publisher nor can be a HTTPS proxy (like Expressway Edge). Rather on-premises Unified Communications devices must not reach internet. In fact, in my job, CUCM is pointing to a HTTPS proxy, but there are other cluster in my company that target a CSSM Satellite, cause the policies of the company. So the best answer is D.

comments.content: Please refer to: "Preferred Architecture for Cisco Collaboration 12.x Enterprise On-Premises Deployments", section "Cisco Smart Software Manager".

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
should be D:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/admin/12_0_1/systemConfig/cucm_b_system-configuration-guide-1201/cucm_b_system-configuration-guide-1201_chapter_01011001.html

The Cisco Smart Software Manager satellite can be deployed in either Connected or Disconnected mode, depending on whether the satellite can connect directly to cisco.com.
Connected—Used when there is connectivity to cisco.com directly from the Smart Software Manager satellite. Smart account synchronization occurs automatically.
Disconnected—Used when there is no connectivity to cisco.com from the Smart Software Manager satellite.
-> "Smart Account synchronization must be manually uploaded and downloaded."

Not A: ASA can not be a Cisco Smart Software Manager satellite
Not B: UCM subscriber can not be a HTTPS proxy
Not C: No IPsec to Smart-Account

choices.D: manual exchange of information between Cisco UCM and Cisco Smart Software Manager to associate and reserve the licenses
choices.B: use of a Cisco UCM subscriber node as an HTTPS proxy to communicate with the Cisco Smart Software Manager
choices.A: setup of a Cisco ASA to provide a Cisco Smart Software Manager satellite system for license reservation
choices.C: configuration of an IPsec policy to secure the communication between Cisco UCM Publisher and Cisco Smart Software Manager

discussion.content:
he correct command that an engineer must run on the SIP dial peer to configure in-band DTMF relay for the third-party application is:

D. dtmf-relay rtp-nte

This command ensures that the in-band DTMF relay (using RTP-NTE, which stands for RTP Named Telephone Events) is used, which is supported by many SIP-based applications and devices. It allows DTMF tones to be sent over the RTP stream rather than through out-of-band signaling mechanisms like SIP INFO or KPML.

If a different type of DTMF relay such as sip-kpml is globally configured, using rtp-nte at the dial-peer level ensures that this specific dial peer will use the correct method for in-band DTMF relay

questions.question_text: A Cisco voice gateway is configured to use a sip-kpml DTMF relay in global settings. A new SIP dial peer is configured for a third-party application that only supports an in-band DTMF relay. Which command must an engineer run on the dial peer?

choices.C: < 3 percent packet loss and < 60 ms jitter
choices.B: < 1 percent packet loss and < 30 ms jitter
choices.A: < 10 percent packet loss and < 10 ms jitter
choices.D: < 9 percent packet loss and < 30 ms jitter

discussion.content: The correct answer, B. < 1 percent packet loss and < 30 ms jitter, is found on page 313 of the document. It specifies that for voice traffic, a delay of less than 150 ms, jitter of less than 30 ms, and packet loss of less than 1 percent are required to maintain quality(CiscoPress-CCNP-and-CCI…)
B. < 1 percent packet loss and < 30 ms jitter

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B. Voice calls, either one-to-one or on a conference connection capability, require the following: ≤ 150 ms of one-way latency from mouth to ear (per the ITU G.114 standard) / ≤ 30 ms jitter / ≤ 1 percent packet loss

questions.question_text: What is the maximum one-way packet loss and jitter for voice before quality issues arise?

choices.D: Set Toll fraud TCL script on the gateway.
choices.B: Set Use Restriction attribute of ID/Name Presentation of Transferring Party to true.
choices.A: Set Service Parameter Block Offnet to Offnet transfer to true.
choices.C: Block transfers on a per gateway configuration on Cisco UCM.

discussion.content:
Configure a setting for the Block OffNet to Offnet Transfer service parameter:
■■ True: Select this option to cancel transfers between two external (OffNet)
gateways.
■■ False: Select this option to allow transfers between two external (OffNet)
gateways. This is the default option.
A. Set Service Parameter Block Offnet to Offnet transfer to true.

questions.question_text: A company recently received a CDR bill. Upon analysis, the administrator sees a vast number of transfers to PSTN from incoming PSTN calls. How can this toll fraud scenario be remediated?
